Content Team's Author Profile
PUBLISHED ON September 03, 2025
meta_description: A step-by-step guide to resetting a Bosch dishwasher. Learn what errors and issues a reset can fix, how to do a soft reset, and how to do a hard reset.
excerpt: Learn how to reset a Bosch dishwasher to fix common errors and issues. We w...
content:
If your Bosch dishwasher buttons aren’t responding, the machine won’t start, or a power issue caused it to stop mid-cycle and now your appliance is filled with water and stuck, you might want to try a quick reset. It is the most efficient way to handle minor issues with any appliance, and it is the first step in any bigger troubleshooting process. There is no need to dig out the rubber gloves and a sponge, resetting your machine takes only a few minutes, and will have the dishwasher back in action and running smoothly.

If your dishwasher will not start a cycle, the first thing you should try is a reset. A dishwasher not starting can be due to any number of things, from control board issues to power supply problems. Resetting the appliance will clear temporary problems and return the dishwasher to a normal operating state, while often keeping your saved settings intact. There are a number of minor issues that can be easily resolved with a reset, some of which we outline in this section.

When you run into issues with your Bosch Dishwasher, start with a soft reset, it’s the quickest, safest fix before diving into bigger repairs. A soft reset is a built-in feature that cancels the current cycle, drains the machine, and restarts the control panel without cutting power or erasing your settings. Unlike unplugging the appliance, which takes longer and may erase your preferences, a soft reset refreshes the system, clears minor glitches or cycle errors, and gives your dishwasher a clean slate without extra hassle.

Note: The button you will use to reset most Bosch dishwasher models is the "start" button. Some older models designate specific buttons, like the "Power" button or "Cancel" button for the reset function, if so, it should be clearly labeled below the button. If you do not see this feature, and the start button does not work you may need to look up the instructions for your exact model number, there may be a combination of buttons you need to press and hold, for example "Start" + "Cancel" at the same time.

The hope is that a soft reset will drain your appliance and get the dishwasher working again. If the soft reset doesn’t work for your Bosch dishwasher, or the appliance won’t reset at all, you can take it a step further and perform a hard reset.

A hard reset, often called a power cycle, is exactly what it sounds like. You cut power to the appliance, allowing it to fully shut down and reset. At home, a common way to fix technical issues is simply unplugging a device and plugging it back in. With a dishwasher, however, unplugging it can be tedious since it often requires uninstalling the unit. For this reason, we recommend using your circuit breaker instead, which is much easier and just as effective. However, when using this method, be sure to exercise caution. Always check which other appliances share the same electrical circuit to avoid accidentally disrupting their operation or causing potential hazards.

A hard reset fully reboots the dishwasher, allowing the internal controls to reset completely. It clears the software, stops any processes causing issues, and gives the appliance a fresh start. The control board reboots entirely, forcing all systems to restart. You should use a hard reset if the soft reset doesn’t resolve the problem or if your Bosch dishwasher is completely unresponsive.

The advancements in technology for our household appliances mean that we sometimes experience minor problems or glitches that cause performance issues, Bosch dishwashers are no exception. The first line of defense when you run into issues should be a reset. Whether your dishwasher won't run, the buttons won't work, or you are getting unexpected error codes, a simple reset will save you a lot of worry and time.

If you have performed a reset and the dishwasher still won't run, or if the same issue keeps occurring, this indicates an underlying problem that needs investigation. You should stop using the dishwasher until you troubleshoot and identify the cause. If the appliance is displaying an error code, consult the user manual to determine what it means. We also offer additional dishwasher repair guides to help you through the process, as well as the OEM Bosch dishwasher parts you may need to get your appliance running again.

meta_description: Discover how to reset your Frigidaire fridge! Learn when and why this simple fix can solve common issues, from temperature fluctuations to electronic glitches.
excerpt: Resetting your Frigidaire fridge could be the answer to your refrigerator w...
content:
Is your Frigidaire fridge acting up, leaving you with lukewarm drinks and thawing food? Resetting your Frigidaire refrigerator can often work wonders, and help you tackle issues from temperature problems to control panel glitches. In this article, we'll show how to perform a soft reset and a hard reset of your Frigidaire fridge and help you understand when and why it might be necessary, such as after a power surge or when the fridge is displaying an error code. Whether you're facing a minor glitch or major malfunctions, a reset could be just the ticket to restore your appliance's cool confidence.

First, check if your fridge has a Reset button on the control panel at the front of the fridge. Once you have located it, press and hold the button for 5 seconds. If there is no Reset button, press and hold the Crush button for 5 seconds instead. You may see lights flashing on the control panel flash or hear a beeping as the fridge returns to its default settings. Once the reset process is complete, monitor how your refrigerator is performing over the next few hours to ensure that it is functioning properly again.

If using the Reset button or Crush button does not reset the refrigerator, you can perform a hard reset instead. Locate the circuit breaker in your home and look for the switch that corresponds to the refrigerator. Flip the switch to the off position and wait at least 5 minutes to allow the refrigerator to completely power down. Turn the switch back on and allow the fridge to recalibrate itself. You should hear the compressor and fans running, which indicates that power has been restored. Once the fridge is fully powered up you can check to see if it's functioning properly and if there are no longer any error codes or control panel issues.

Knowing when and how to reset your Frigidaire fridge can be a valuable skill for maintaining its optimal performance and extending its lifespan. Whether you're experiencing temperature fluctuations, malfunctioning displays, or other issues, a reset can often provide a simple solution. By following the steps outlined in this guide and understanding the common reasons why a reset may be necessary, you can ensure that your Frigidaire refrigerator continues to keep your food fresh and your kitchen running smoothly. However, if resetting does not resolve the issue, then your fridge may need repair. You can use our model search feature to find genuine OEM Frigidaire refrigerator parts for your appliance.  With proper care and maintenance, your Frigidaire fridge will continue to serve you well for years to come.

title: Why is Your Fridge Making Humming Noises?
author:
WRITTEN BYCONTENT TEAM
The PartSelect Content Team has a passion for DIY and we pride ourselves on being a resource for quality, expert content to help you accomplish any DIY project. Alongside our expert repair technicians, our team of experienced technical writers works to provide safe and reliable information on all tasks and jobs around your home. We spend time learning about the problems and projects that our customers are working on, and we make it our job to answer key questions and provide resources for every step along the way. Repairs and DIY projects are what we do, and the PartSelect Content Team wants to help you do them, too.
Content Team's Author Profile
PUBLISHED ON November 17, 2023
meta_description: Learn more about why hearing humming, buzzing, and rattling noises from your refrigerator aren't as bad as you think, but some noises should make you concerned!
excerpt: Ever wonder why your refrigerator hums or buzzes and makes so much noise, a...
content:
Quiet humming or buzzing noises coming from your refrigerator are completely normal. Refrigerator compressors normally produce a low humming noise during various portions of the day, since they're essentially the refrigerator's motor. The evaporator also produces noise, although it's usually not as loud as the compressor is. However, if there is a louder-than-usual hum coming from your refrigerator, it may be a sign of frost buildup around the evaporator, or an aging and failing compressor. Then, if you are hearing extremely loud humming noises, there may be an issue with the condenser or evaporator fan that we will break down for you how to fix below, along with step-by-step video guides!

Occasional, low noises coming from your refrigerator are completely normal, and nothing to be concerned about – but there are definitely some noises that you will want to take more seriously than others. Here is a list of most refrigerator noises you'll hear, and what they mean:

If the evaporator fan in your refrigerator is blocked by ice, if its airway is blocked by food items, or if its motor is bad and needs replacing, your refrigerator will begin to hum or buzz loudly. Luckily, the evaporator can be fixed, and doing so is a repair that anyone can do!

Depending on your refrigerator model, food items can block and clog the airway of the evaporator fan, preventing it from properly distributing cool air within the cabinet of the refrigerator and causing both the compressor and evaporator to work harder and hum or buzz distinctly loud. Simply moving food out of the way of the fan and clearing off any built-up frost should fix the humming and noise issue.

Evaporator fans help maintain the internal temperature in your refrigerator. They pull warm air from the appliance through the evaporator coils to cool it. Depending on the model of refrigerator, the evaporator fan motor may also be used to circulate that cooled air. However, if the defrost system malfunctions or if any parts within it don't work properly, the fan mechanism will experience frost buildup and produce a humming or buzzing noise. If your refrigerator is experiencing defrost issues and significant frost buildup, we have a general how-to guide on how to fix it!

If the evaporator fan blade does not move freely within the evaporator mechanism, it means that the motor is bad or broken and needs replacing in order to function properly. Fortunately, we have a huge inventory of OEM refrigerator evaporator fan motors, and the guide you need to properly replace it:

Below is a general video guide showing how to replace a refrigerator evaporator fan motor.

The defrost system within your refrigerator, made up of the defrost timer, thermostat, and heater, is designed to melt ice and frost buildup within the cooling systems of the fridge. This is done to ensure your food items are kept cold at all times, without the risk of frost or ice building up and causing issues. If either of these parts fails or stops working properly, ice and frost will buildup and the evaporator fan will eventually begin making a humming or buzzing noise.

For this repair, you will need a screwdriver, and you may require a wire stripper and crimper, heat-shrinking tubes, a heat gun, and a new defrost thermostat which you can find in our wide range of OEM refrigerator thermostats.

Below is a general video guide on how to replace the defrost thermostat.

If you've replaced the defrost thermostat and frost is continuing to buildup, it's likely an issue with the defrost heater, which is supposed to activate and melt any and all ice or frost. Replacing this part is not difficult, and likely will only require a screwdriver and a new defrost heater which you can find in our selection of OEM refrigerator elements and burners.

Below is a general video guide for how to replace a refrigerator defrost heater.

If you've replaced your refrigerator's defrost thermostat and heater, and you are still finding frost buildup around the evaporator fan causing it to hum, the defrost timer is likely bad and not running for as long as necessary. For this repair, you will need a screwdriver and a new defrost timer, which you can conveniently find in our inventory of OEM refrigerator timers!

Below is a general video guide on how to replace the defrost timer.

If you've replaced the evaporator fan motor, defrost timer, thermostat, and heater, and your refrigerator is continuing to produce loud or abnormal humming or buzzing noises, it is likely an issue with its compressor. Compressor repairs are quite costly and difficult to do, even for repair-savvy individuals, because of the hazardous and toxic materials, like refrigerant, used within refrigerators – this is why we recommend compressor repairs be left to qualified repair technicians.

For all other refrigerator or non-refrigerator-related repair and home improvement blog articles, stay tuned to our PartSelect blog! And for the appliances and equipment in your home that need repairing, we have you covered with OEM parts at PartSelect.com!

title: How to Fix a Fridge That’s Making a Loud Knocking Noise
author:
WRITTEN BYSARAH BURDEN
Sarah works closely with our in-house repair technician to bring our "how-to" articles to life. Regularly featured in our video live streams, she demonstrates that DIY repairs can be accessible to anyone!
Sarah Burden's Author Profile
PUBLISHED ON January 05, 2026
meta_description: A knocking or banging noise from your fridge can be a normal sound or something wrong with your compressor, ice maker, or fan blades.  Learn about fridge knocking noises with this guide.
excerpt: Fridges make a variety of banging, popping, and knocking noises during thei...
content:
It’s normal for loud banging or knocking noises to come from your fridge occasionally. Your fridge runs with on/off cycles and often contains moving parts, heavy objects, and ice that will clink and clang. All of these elements can make jolting, knocking, or banging noises as part of regular operation. But that doesn’t mean your fridge making a banging noise should be ignored. Sometimes, non-repair issues need to be solved, like an uneven level or a frosting issue. If these don’t fix the noise, you may need to perform a repair on the fan blades, ice maker, or compressor. If you’re lucky, what you’re hearing is just a normal cycle switch-on noise from the compressor, ice falling heavily into an empty compartment, or the ice maker arm moving into position. Whether it’s nothing to worry about, a quick fix, or something that involves a part replacement, this guide will help stop the startling noises and get your fridge back to normal.

Sometimes your fridge will make noises that sound like bangs or knocks or sharp sudden sounds, and it can be a little surprising. However, these noises can occur for a variety of reasons, from completely normal fridge operation to something that requires further examination. Here are some things to check before you worry about bigger operational issues with your appliance.

If your fridge has an ice maker, it is common for the ice to bang loudly as it falls into the bin. This can be jolting and often lines up with "evening banging" if you've been using your ice maker a lot throughout the day and night. As the ice refills in the evening, people often report loud banging noises that coincide with the nighttime, but it's mainly because their ice supply is being refilled from empty, which makes louder noises as ice falls into an empty plastic bin. Some noises are also common during the ice maker’s “harvest cycle”. For example, sometimes when the ice maker's arm is pushing ice out, or going back into position after pushing ice into your bin, it can make a slow clunking noise; another normal sound that is no cause for concern. However, if the noises from your ice maker sound worse and unnatural, or are becoming more regular, jump down to our Ice Maker section for inspection tips.

“Water hammer” is a sound that occurs sometimes in fridges, faucets and other appliances with a water line, and it happens when the water valve on the appliance opens and closes, causing a pressure change accompanied by a bang/pop. This can be caused by fast-closing water valves (like many ice makers/fridges have), high water pressure in the home, or issues with the piping/plumbing. Although not a critical issue, if it's annoying you and can be traced back to the refrigerator's water line, installing a water hammer arrestor on the cold-water supply line in front of the fridge's inlet valve can solve the problem.

For this simple job you’ll just need to purchase a water hammer arrestor, sized for a 3/8-inch or half-inch line depending on your fridge. An adjustable wrench and some Teflon tape will help make the task simpler.

If a lower-pitched or more mechanical thump or hum is the noise you're describing and it's a routine one-time sound that seems to align with when the cooling cycle would be coming on or off, it's likely the compressor functioning as it should. Your fridge is constantly cycling between cooling and defrost modes, and the compressor "compresses" refrigerant to control the cooling cycle when the fridge needs to come down in temperature. A noise when this cycle commences is normal and expected, but as we'll explain later in the article, there are times when compressor noises can be a cause for concern.

Sometimes, when the refrigerator is getting cold again after being opened, plastic and metal components, particularly the evaporator coil, can make sharp popping noises as they contract with the increased blast of cold as the refrigerator re-cools. If the banging noise tends to occur in conjunction with the sounds of the compressor doing its thing, this is not a cause for concern, and just a natural function of the refrigerator's cooling process.

Sometimes, if your fridge was not correctly leveled, ice, lighter objects, condiments, and whatnot can move around, especially if they were moved recently or the fridge was recently closed aggressively (thanks kids!). No, your fridge isn't haunted by people moving stuff around inside, it could just be unlevel, and the glass surfaces of most shelves combined with glass/plastic bottles can make it easy for things to shift internally.

This is a simple job that will just require a wrench and a basic spirit level (you can use a free phone app if you don’t have a physical level). Generally, you’ll want your fridge to be mostly level with a very slight lean towards the back, to allow the doors to close more easily after a light push.

If you’ve gone through the above list of regular non-repair causes of a noisy fridge and determined that none of these are the issue, you may be dealing with a faulty part that requires inspection.

This is the most likely culprit for a banging or knocking noise that won’t go away. If the compressor itself is failing, unfortunately it’s a repair we don’t recommend doing yourself, as it can involve working with dangerous refrigerant, but there are also instances where the issue can be fixed before a complete replacement is required. Here’s how to check your fridge’s compressor.

There are two different types of fan blades in your fridge that can cause banging or knocking noises if they’re warped, affected by ice or debris, or are hitting other internal parts. These are the evaporator fan blades, and the condenser fan blades, and we will walk you through troubleshooting both. A good clue that it's fan blades causing the issue is if the knocking or banging noise you're hearing is less sudden and isolated, and more repetitive and predictable. Something closer to a "knock knock knock knock knock" than a sudden, sharp "bang"! As the various fans in your fridge spin and come into contact with things, it will happen repeatedly, and so will the noise. If this describes the sound you're hearing, look no further.

Evaporator fan problems occur when this part, which lives in your freezer and circulates cold air throughout your appliance, freezes up partially, or comes into contact with ice as it spins. The resulting noise can be constant banging or knocking, which you might be able to identify by its consistency, and location being pinpointed to the freezer. Here’s how to check your evaporator fan.

Condenser fan motor issues can happen when this part, which is located at the bottom rear of your fridge, near the condenser coils, is coming into contact with other parts, debris under the fridge, dust bunnies, or is otherwise loose. The condenser fan helps cool your condenser coils and compressor, and starts running during the cooling cycle when your compressor kicks on. If the noise does seem to be related to this compressor cycle, but you’ve not been able to attribute the noise to the compressor itself, the condenser fan motor is one to check.

As we covered above, some noises are normal as part of the ice maker’s "harvest" cycle, as internal components move and activate to fill your ice molds, dump them into your tray, and move the ice towards your dispenser. But humidity can cause excess ice to form in your freezer and around your ice maker, and the ice maker will still try to carry out its duties even when things are frozen over or ice is in the way. This can cause unnatural banging/knocking noises. Here’s how to check things out.

Refrigerators work hard to perform their cycles and functions, and some knocking, banging, buzzing, and humming are all to be expected, but it shouldn’t be something that causes you to constantly jump out of your seat, and that’s why we’re glad you found this guide! Whether it’s a regular noise from your refrigerator that causes the occasional jump scare, a quick issue solved by a re-levelling or defrosting, or something a little more involved, we hope this article has helped you get to the bottom of your fridge knocking issue. If you’ve determined that a faulty part is at the root of it all, remember you can find thousands of top OEM fridge parts right here at PartSelect to help your fridge be seen and not heard!

title: Guide to Dishwasher Cycles
author:
WRITTEN BYSARAH BURDEN
Sarah works closely with our in-house repair technician to bring our "how-to" articles to life. Regularly featured in our video live streams, she demonstrates that DIY repairs can be accessible to anyone!
Sarah Burden's Author Profile
PUBLISHED ON October 31, 2025
meta_description: Learn about the most common dishwasher cycles, how long they run, and when to use each one to get the best clean and energy savings from your dishwasher.
excerpt: Still hitting “normal” on your dishwasher every time? Learn what each cycle...
content:
Each time you start a dishwasher cycle, it goes through four different phases: pre-wash, main wash, rinse, and dry. However, there are numerous cycle types to choose from; which one should you be using and what’s the difference between them all? In this article, we’ll discuss the most common cycles found on dishwashers, their different functions, and when you should use them, along with some tips for optimal cleaning.

Depending on the age and technology of your dishwasher, you may have dozens of cycle options to choose from to clean your dishes. If you’ve just been selecting “normal” every time, there may be an alternative option to fit your dishes' needs.

This option may also be called Rinse & Hold (GE), Rinse Only (GE, KitchenAid, Frigidaire, Samsung), or Prewash (Maytag). The rinse cycle will prevent food from drying onto your dishes and help prevent any smells from forming.

I know we stated at the start of the article not to rinse your dishes prior to loading, but this cycle has a time and place.  It is a handy feature when you’re loading the dishwasher at one time (say after dinner), but don’t plan to run a load until a later time (after breakfast the next day for example). If you are loading the dishwasher and immediately turning it on, there’s no need to do this rinse cycle first, as that’s taken care of during normal operation.

The rinse cycle is very quick (typically just a few minutes) and is run without detergent.

This will be the shortest cycle that actually washes your dishes. Depending on your model, this cycle may be called Quick Wash (Whirlpool, Frigidaire), Express Wash (KitchenAid, Bosch),1 Hour Wash (Maytag, Frigidaire), or Glass Cycle (GE).

This cycle should be used for lightly soiled items, or dishware that you need to clean quickly (such as cooking or baking dishes you want to use again later). The quick cycle is probably not sufficient to clean baked-on food, and it may not fully dry your dishes.

You can expect this option to take between 30-60 minutes to clean your dishes.

The normal cycle on a dishwasher may also be called Standard or Regular. This is the typical setting most will use, as it will provide a thorough clean for daily-use dishes.

Unless you have heavily soiled cookware, or other special washing needs, this cycle option will fit the bill. When running a full load, this option is going to be more energy efficient and likely save you time over hand washing every dish.

A normal cycle can take between 1.5 to 2 hours to complete.

The Eco cycle uses less energy and water by using a lower water temperature and less water but extends the cycle length, so that you still have thoroughly cleaned dishes. It may be called an Eco Mode, Eco (Bosch), or Energy Saver (Frigidaire) as well.

If you aren’t concerned with the length the cycle runs for, this option could replace the “normal” one if your model of dishwasher has it. An eco cycle works great for regular-use dishes but may not be suitable for heavily soiled or burnt-on food. It may not fully dry your dishes either, in order to conserve energy.

The run time will vary depending on your model, but you can expect an Eco cycle to take about 3 hours to complete.

More modern dishwashers have sensors, which can detect how dirty your dishes are. The sensor will relay this information, and the dishwasher will adjust the water level, temperatures, and length of the cycle to ensure your dishes are fully cleaned. Other names for this type of cycle include Sensor (Frigidaire, Whirlpool, Maytag), ProWash (KitchenAid), AutoSense (GE), Smart Auto (Samsung) and Mixed-Load.

This option can replace the default “normal” cycle option, as it will adjust each time you run a load of dishes for an optimal clean. The auto mode is also ideal if you are washing a variety of items, such as pots and pans with your regular plates and cutlery.

This cycle can take longer to complete, and the time will vary with each use. You can expect your dishwasher to run for 2 to 3 hours, depending on how dirty the dishes are. Similar to a washing machine with sensors, the “time left” on display may fluctuate throughout the cycle.

This cycle is meant for your most soiled dishes and cookware. It may also go by Heavy Wash (Frigidaire), Pots & Pans (Samsung), Cookware, Heavy Soil, Tough (KitchenAid), or Intensive. This cycle is going to use higher temperatures and more water to get the job done, but that’s what it takes to tackle burnt on messes or greasy cookware.

This won’t be (and shouldn’t be) your go-to daily use cycle. You’ll most likely use this one after a busy cooking day, such as when doing meal-prep or hosting a holiday meal.

You can expect a heavy cycle to take at least 3 hours to complete.

Dishwashers have additional options you can select to better suit your needs. Here are some of the most common ones and how they work. These options are not 'cycles' per se but may appear as buttons on your dishwasher's control panel that are selectable in addition to the cycle options above.

The sanitize option will reach temperatures hot enough to kill 99.99% of food related bacteria. It should be noted that sanitizing and sterilizing are two different functions, and household dishwashers do not get hot enough to sterilize your dishes (the water needs to be at least 250F). Depending on your model, this option may be called Sanitize Cycle, SaniWash, Sani-Rinse, High-Temp Rinse. This is a setting you select in addition to a regular cycle, and the machine will then perform a final rinse at a higher temperature (at least 150F) to sanitize your items.

This option should be selected when you have items like baby bottles, cutting boards or dishes that touched raw meat, or cleaning dishes while there's cold and flu bugs in the house.

Sanitizing can add up to an extra hour to your regular wash cycle.

Selecting a dry option on your dishwasher can add extra time to the cycle, and be a significant source of energy consumption. Below are some of the most common dry options, including some energy efficient choices.

Selecting the heat dry option on your dishwasher will turn on the heating element at the bottom of the tub after the rinse phase. The heat will circulate through the tub and help the water evaporate from your dishes faster. If you are opting to use a heat dry option, be sure to load any plastic dishes on the top rack of the dishwasher to prevent them from melting. Using this option can add an extra 30 minutes to the total cycle time.

The extended dry option functions similar to a regular heat dry but runs for a longer amount of time. This option will increase your dishwasher's energy use and will lengthen the overall cycle time.

The heated rinse option will use a hotter water temperature at the end of the cycle. The hot water will evaporate quicker, leaving you with dry dishes.

For an energy savings option, use fan dry instead of a heated dry. This option uses a fan to circulate either room temperature or hot air(which is less economical but efficient at drying).

This feature is found on newer dishwasher models, where the door will automatically pop open to allow the steam to escape from the tub. If your machine doesn’t have this option, you can replicate the results by manually cracking open the dishwasher door once the cycle has finished.

The delay start option on a dishwasher allows you to pre-select a cycle, and then a later time for it to actually run. Depending on your model, there may be a set delay (4 hours later for example) or you can choose the time, typically in one-hour increments.

In many areas, energy costs are lower overnight, so scheduling the dishwasher to run after you’ve gone to bed can help save on your utility bills. Or if your home has an open floor plan, running the dishwasher right after dinner might be too noisy to enjoy watching TV in the living room. Using the delay start lets you set it and forget and still have clean dishes in the morning.

Using the delay start feature doesn’t change the length of the actual wash cycle; it just prolongs the time when the dishwasher starts running.

Understanding the different dishwasher cycles available on your machine can help you get cleaner dishes, save energy, and extend the life of your appliance. Whether you’re tackling tough, baked-on cookware or just running a quick load of glasses, choosing the right setting makes a noticeable difference in both performance and efficiency. By pairing the correct cycle with proper loading habits and detergent use, you’ll ensure your dishwasher runs at its best, and your dishes come out spotless every time. if your dishwasher's cycles or features aren't working as intended, there may be a problem with one or more of the components responsible for the cycle. You can diagnose the exact issue causing your cycle problems with our dishwasher repair guides and complete your DIY repairs with our OEM dishwasher parts.

title: All About Water Filters
author:
WRITTEN BYSARAH BURDEN
Sarah works closely with our in-house repair technician to bring our "how-to" articles to life. Regularly featured in our video live streams, she demonstrates that DIY repairs can be accessible to anyone!
Sarah Burden's Author Profile
PUBLISHED ON December 18, 2025
meta_description: Learn how fridge water filters trap contaminants, how often to replace them, and the steps to remove and change your filter to ensure clean, safe drinking water.
excerpt:
Is your fridge water filter overdue for a change?
Learn how filters work, w...
content:
If your fridge water has been tasting off, or you've been having issues with it not dispensing water, or not making ice, it may be trying to tell you that it’s time to change the water filter. Your fridge may even have an indicator light or display to alert you as well! If you’ve been putting off this task (or perhaps have never ever changed the water filter), it’s time to start! Why should you bother? Filters help ensure your drinking water is free of contaminants, and keep your water dispenser and ice maker working efficiently. In this article we’ll discuss how a water filter works and what it filters out, how long a water filter lasts, and how often you should change it, along with the steps to remove and replace your fridge water filter.

The water filter in your fridge works by trapping contaminants before they enter the water dispenser or ice maker. The first step is trapping larger particulars like sand or silt to improve the clarity, then medium and microscopic contaminants are absorbed by the carbon core. Over time, the carbon will become saturated with these contaminants and will fail to continue filtering. It is important to change the filter on a regular (typically every 6 months) basis to keep your drinking water fresh.

As water travels, it picks up impurities and contaminants both from the natural environment and from cities, homes, and farms. Water that has not been filtered can contain minerals, chemicals, bacteria, and microscopic organisms that can create an unpleasant flavor and, in some cases, can cause potentially harmful illnesses.

If your home is on municipal water services, it will already be treated for anything harmful, but it may contain the following:

If you get your water from a well, there is the potential for it to contain a variety of potential contaminants. Well water is not required to abide by specific water guidelines. It is the owner’s responsibility to test the well at least once a year (depending on your local conditions) due to continually fluctuating ground conditions. These contaminants are not necessarily present in your well water but are commonly found:

To know exactly what your water filter removes, make sure you read the label of your filter carefully.  If your filter is NSF Certified, you can search the NSF database to understand what your model is certified to protect against. NSF stands for National Sanitation Foundation and the NSF mark is an assurance that your filter has been tested by a trustworthy impartial certification organization, and all of its contaminant reduction assertions are truthful and correct. On your fridge water filter label look for NSF/ANSI 42, which filters "aesthetic effects" like chlorine and sediments (like sand and silt) and improves the taste and odor of your water. For "health effects" looks for NSF/ANSI 53 on the label. This standard removes contaminants like lead, mercury, VOCs, and cysts/parasites. To remove contaminants like nitrates, arsenic, and fluoride, you may require more advanced systems than a fridge water filter, such as reverse osmosis or UV lights.

PartSelect.com only sells NSF certified and OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) water filters. When you purchase the water filter for your specific model of fridge, it is manufacturer guaranteed to fit and treat your water properly. While non-certified or after-market filters may look similar, they do not offer the same filtration and fit guarantee that a certified filter does. An inaccurate size can result in water flowing around the filter instead of through, allowing contaminants into your drinking water. You can read our article on OEM to learn more about the difference OEM products make,

Manufacturers recommend that you change your filter every six months with regular water usage. Most filters are able to process 200-400 gallons of water before becoming clogged, so if a family of 4 drinks the recommended 8-cups of water per day, you should get between 3-6 months out of your filter. If you use your water dispenser more than average or have poor water conditions due to your location, it may need to be changed more frequently.

Other signs you may need to replace your filter:

Failure to change your filter at least every six months will allow contaminants to saturate your filter, causing it to leak the potentially toxic chemicals back into your drinking water. With an outdated filter, your water may even contain more pollutants than unfiltered water. Neglecting to change the filter can also reduce the water pressure in the filtering system and can lead to a buildup of lime scale which can wreak havoc on your appliance. Not to mention, an expired filter could cause a change in taste and odor.

Replacing the filter every six months is a simple maintenance task with so many benefits. If you’re struggling to remember, signing up for a water filter subscription program will remind you. A new filter will be shipped right to your door every six months (or the cycle of your choosing). Simply install the new filter once it arrives, and continue to enjoy fresh, clean drinking water.

The location of the water filter in your fridge will depend on your make and model. With the various styles of fridges available today (top freezer, bottom freezer, French door, or side by side as examples) there isn’t a universal location water filters can be found. Your user manual will be able to tell you the exact location of the filter in your fridge. However here are some common locations to check and the typical method to remove them:

You can also use our Water Filter Finder to find the filter location and appropriate water filter for your refrigerator model.

Just like the location of the water filter, how to remove and replace it will vary depending on your fridge model. No matter what style of fridge you have, changing the water filter is a very simple process that shouldn’t require any tools. Below, we have covered the steps for changing four of the most common types of water filters. If you have a different type, refer to your fridge’s user manual for the exact steps for your model.

This style of water filter will typically be found in the fridge’s interior, or down at the base grille. The steps to change this filter are the same for either location.

After you replace the filter, you should flush the system before drinking the water. A lot of filters are carbon-based and will need to have water run through them to flush out any excess carbon residue, which can produce a bitter taste to your water. This will also get rid of air bubbles caught in the system. Each filter will have its own flush time written in its instruction guide.

Most modern refrigerators will have a water filter indicator light used to notify you when it is time to replace your filter. Some indicator lights or messages will automatically reset once you have installed the new filter, but many do not. If the light is still flashing red or indicating the need to replace it after you have installed your new filter, this is because it needs to be manually reset. Generally, this is done by pressing and holding the button down for a few seconds. For more information, check your user manual for instructions specific to your model.

Regularly replacing the water filter is essential for both the quality of your drinking water and the health of your refrigerator. Filters play a critical role in removing impurities, improving taste, and preventing harmful contaminants from entering your water supply. Neglecting to replace them can lead to poor water quality, unpleasant odors, and even damage to your appliance. By following the manufacturer’s guidelines for replacing the filter every six months, you ensure fresh, safe water for your household. A simple routine like this not only protects your family but also extends the life of your fridge, making it a small but impactful step toward better home maintenance.

title: What is the Ideal Temperature for a Fridge?
author:
WRITTEN BYSARAH BURDEN
Sarah works closely with our in-house repair technician to bring our "how-to" articles to life. Regularly featured in our video live streams, she demonstrates that DIY repairs can be accessible to anyone!
Sarah Burden's Author Profile
PUBLISHED ON September 16, 2025
meta_description: The temperature in a fridge should be kept below 40F to prevent bacteria growth.  We’ll show you how to adjust this setting along with providing food safety tips.
excerpt: The temperature in a fridge should be kept below 40F to prevent bacteria gr...
content:
Ensuring your fridge is set to a specific temperature not only keeps your food fresh, but it is also an important safety feature. When food is stored at the optimal temperature, it prevents harmful bacteria from growing. So what temperature is ideal for both your fresh food in the fridge, and frozen items in the freezer? Is the coldest setting the best to use? In this article we’ll discuss the different options for your fridge and freezer, food storage tips, and how to adjust the settings for your refrigerator.

To prevent foodborne illnesses, your fridge needs to be kept at a temperature under 40F (4C). The ideal range however is between 35-38F (or approximately 1-3C) so that your food is thoroughly chilled without freezing. To keep the items in your freezer frozen solid, you will want the temperature to be set to 0F or lower (-18C or colder).

An inexpensive thermometer placed in the fridge can help ensure that the appliance is set to (and maintaining) the correct temperature. Some factors to consider when it comes to your fridge temperature are the age of appliance and how full it is. An older or fully stocked fridge may need a lower setting to maintain a cooler temperature. It’s important to note that you shouldn’t jam your fridge or freezer full, as air flow is essential to maintaining the temperature.

Whether your fridge is an older base model, or a newer style with a digital display, adjusting the temperature is a simple task.

If your fridge has a dial to adjust the temperature, it's as simple as turning the knob to raise or lower the temperature. Most fridge models will have a range of 1 to 5 for the settings, but what do these mean as far as temperatures go? The higher the number, the colder the temperature. The lower the number, the warmer the temperature. If you set the dial at “1” it should keep your fridge around 39F, whereas a setting of 5 should be around 33F so that your food doesn’t freeze. Most models will have an “ideal temperature” marker on the dial. This is a good setting to start with, and you can then adjust the temperature dial from there if you need more or less cooling.

If you have a fridge with a digital control board, you should be able to select the exact temperature you want for the fridge and freezer. As mentioned above, your fridge should be below 40F to prevent bacteria from growing, and the freezer should be below 0F to keep your food frozen. The process to select the temperature will vary depending on your fridge model, but it should be very straightforward, typically just pushing an up-arrow or down-arrow button to adjust the temperature.

While the temperature in your fridge is essential to prevent bacteria from growing, where you place different foods in your fridge also helps keep things fresher for longer. There are different temperature “zones” with the door being one of the warmer areas, and the bottom shelves or crispers being the cooler areas. It is good food-safety practice to not store highly perishable items like milk on the door, and to keep items like meat on the lower shelves. You can learn more, including how to set your crisper humidity levels, by reading our article on proper food storage.

If there is bad weather that may cause a power outage, there are also steps you can take to help prevent your food from spoiling. Our article on food safety during a power outage can help you prepare for these events.

If you’ve tried adjusting the temperature in your fridge, and it isn’t staying cold, it’s likely that a part has failed. The fans or compressor may not be working, which is going to leave you with a warm fridge and spoiled food. If you don’t hear any fans running, this may indicate that you have a problem with the controls, which could be a dial or electronic. If the fans on your refrigerator are running but not the compressor, it is likely a problem with the start device for that compressor. Most compressors use either a relay overload device or a start device. You can learn how to correct these issues with our article about refrigerators not cooling.

If the temperature setting in your fridge is too low, it may cause some items to freeze, especially those located at the back. Bumping the temperature up a degree or two should resolve this. If there is persistent frost however, there may be an issue with one of the controls. If the temperature control, damper control, or the electronic control have failed, it can result in temperature imbalances in your fridge which could be causing your fresh food to freeze. Learn how to diagnose and resolve this issue with our article about why your fridge is freezing food.

Maintaining the ideal temperature of 35-38F in your fridge is essential for keeping you and your household safe. This keeps your food fresh and helps to prevent bacteria from growing, which can cause various foodborne illnesses. Adjusting the temperature is a simple process, and keeping a thermometer in the fridge is an inexpensive way to check that temperatures are maintained. If your fridge is running hot or starts freezing food, we can help walk you through a repair and provide genuine replacement parts for your fridge.

Keep your fridge cold and your food fresh all summer long with this guide.

Don't let a power outage ruin your good food! Stay safe with these tips.

title: How to Use Power Cool on a Samsung Fridge
author:
WRITTEN BYCONTENT TEAM
The PartSelect Content Team has a passion for DIY and we pride ourselves on being a resource for quality, expert content to help you accomplish any DIY project. Alongside our expert repair technicians, our team of experienced technical writers works to provide safe and reliable information on all tasks and jobs around your home. We spend time learning about the problems and projects that our customers are working on, and we make it our job to answer key questions and provide resources for every step along the way. Repairs and DIY projects are what we do, and the PartSelect Content Team wants to help you do them, too.
Content Team's Author Profile
PUBLISHED ON May 15, 2024
meta_description: The Power Cool and Power Freeze feature in a Samsung fridge is used to rapidly cool down the fridge and freezer. Learn how to get the most out of them.
excerpt: Don't let your groceries go to waste. Learn how to use the Power Cool featu...
content:
Whether you're restocking groceries or preparing for gatherings, Power Cool is a feature available on many Samsung refrigerators, designed to rapidly lower the temperature inside the fridge compartment. Power Cool is commonly used after grocery shopping, when preparing for gatherings, or during hot weather conditions. To activate Power Cool, you can use either the control panel on the refrigerator or the Family Hub app. Factors influencing the duration of Power Cool include initial temperature, amount and temperature of contents, room temperature, refrigerator age, frequency of door openings, and the size and model of the refrigerator. If Power Cool is not working, you can try resetting the refrigerator to restore it to its original settings. Ultimately, Samsung's Power Cool feature offers a convenient way to ensure your food stays cool and your groceries remain fresh for longer. Follow this guide to learn how to get the most out of this feature!

Power Cool allows you to lower the temperature inside the refrigerator compartment quickly. When Power Cool is activated, the refrigerator begins to run the compressor at a higher capacity to help cool down the interior rapidly. This feature allows you to instantly chill the food items stored in the fridge compartment.

The Power Freeze feature works similarly to the Power Cool feature by running the compressor at a higher capacity, but it is used for the freezer compartment. It is designed to rapidly freeze items and is usually activated when you need to quickly freeze fresh groceries or items such as ice cream. The Power Freeze function also shortens the amount of time needed to produce ice from the ice maker. It is best to activate Power Freeze one full day before you place items in the freezer. Once it is activated, Power Freeze will run for 50 hours before gradually returning to the normal freezer temperature. To activate and deactivate it, simply press and hold the Freezer button for 3 seconds or select the Power Freeze option in your Family Hub account.

It generally takes approximately two hours for the fridge to fully cool after Power Cool is activated. Once the temperature reaches 1°C the Power Cool function switches off. After several hours the fridge will gradually return to its normal temperature.

Power Cool is a powerful and convenient way to cool the interior of the fridge. You can use Power Cool in the following scenarios to help get the most out of your appliance:

Locate the "Fridge" button on the control panel of your refrigerator. Press and hold the button for 3 seconds and wait for the corresponding display to light up. This indicates that Power Cool is now running You can switch off the Power Cool function by pressing and holding the button again until the indicator light switches off.

First ensure that your Samsung refrigerator is connected to your home Wi-Fi network and that you have the SmartThings App installed on your phone or tablet. Log in to your account and connect the refrigerator to your Family Hub account. Navigate to the Fridge Manager button and click on it. Tap on the toggle labeled Power Cool to activate Power Cool in your fridge. Once Power Cool has been activated, you can monitor the temperature inside the refrigerator from your phone. You may also receive notifications or updates through the Family Hub app.

The duration of the Power Cool feature can be influenced by several factors:

If the Power Cool feature is not working, it may be due to a minor system glitch in the refrigerator. It is common for users to run into technical problems every so often. You can fix this issue by resetting the refrigerator. This will clear out any old settings and restore the fridge to its default settings. You can follow any of the methods below to rest your Samsung fridge.

Locate the Reset button on the control panel on the refrigerator. Once you have found it, press and hold the button for 3 - 5 seconds. The control panel should light up as it resets. Once the display has returned to normal check that the fridge is running properly again.

If your Samsung fridge does not have a Reset button, you can use the Power Cool and Power Freeze buttons to reset the fridge instead. Press and hold the buttons together, at the same time for 10 seconds. You should hear a chime as the refrigerator resets itself.

Open the Family Hub App on your phone and click on the Settings button. Scroll down to the option that says "About Family Hub". Select the "Factory data reset" option and then press on the "RESET" option. The app will then prompt you to press "RESET" again. Finally, press "Delete all data".

Go to the electrical panel in your home and find the switch that corresponds to the refrigerator. Flip the switch and leave it turned off for at least five minutes. This allows the electronic controls and components to reset completely. Turn the switch back on and allow the fridge to power on and stabilize. Verify that the refrigerator is functioning properly again after the hard reset.

A common problem that Samsung fridge users face is the Power Freeze function cycling on on its own. This typically indicates a stuck key or an internal fault within the display panel on the front of the refrigerator. You can browse our list of genuine OEM Samsung refrigerator parts to find a replacement for your model! To remove the display panel, first locate and unthread the mounting screws(s) located on the underside of the panel. Once you have done so you can grip the bottom of the panel with both hands and pull it out of the housing. Disconnect the wire connector and discard the old panel. Attach the wire connector to your new display panel and pop it back into the housing. Remember to rethread the mounting screw to hold it in place.

Samsung's Power Cool feature is a powerful tool designed to rapidly cool down your refrigerator's interior, ensuring your groceries stay fresh for longer. By activating this feature strategically during periods of high usage or after loading in a large batch of warm items, you can maintain optimal temperature levels and preserve the quality of your stored food. Remember that while Power Cool is incredibly effective, using it excessively can lead to unnecessary energy consumption. So be sure to follow the guidelines set out above on when and how to use the Power Cool feature for maximum efficiency.
